title: Add pcb_copper_text rendering support with knockout text feature
description: Add support for rendering pcb_copper_text circuit-json elements, including automatic mirroring for bottom layer text, rotation support, and text alignment. Implement knockout text rendering feature that displays text as a cutout from a filled background rectangle, with configurable padding.
body:
Summary
- Add support for rendering `pcb_copper_text` circuit-json elements, including automatic mirroring for bottom layer text, rotation support, and text alignment
- Implement knockout text rendering feature that displays text as a cutout from a filled background rectangle, with configurable padding

 Changes

- **convert-element-to-primitive.ts**: Add converter for `pcb_copper_text` elements, parsing font size, knockout padding, and all text properties
- **draw-primitives.ts**: 
  - Refactor text alignment offset calculation into reusable `getAlignOffset` function
  - Add `shouldMirrorText` helper to handle automatic mirroring for bottom copper layer
  - Implement `drawKnockoutText` function using destination-out compositing to cut text from background
- **types.ts**: Extend `Text` interface with `is_mirrored`, `is_knockout`, and `knockout_padding` properties
- **copper-text.fixture.tsx**: Add fixture demonstrating copper text on top/bottom layers with rotation and knockout variants

title: Improve via geometry creation for JSCAD
description: Refactors via geometry generation in the PCB board model by introducing dedicated functions for creating via copper and board drill geometries, enhancing maintainability and clarity.
body: This pull request refactors via geometry generation in the PCB board model, introducing dedicated functions for creating via copper and board drill geometries, and updates related type names for consistency. The main logic for via handling is now more explicit and modular, improving both maintainability and clarity. **Via geometry generation improvements:** * Added new functions `createViaCopper` and `createViaBoardDrill` in `src/geoms/via-geoms.ts` to generate via copper (barrel and annular rings) and board drill geometries, respectively. These replace the previous approach of treating vias as plated holes. * Updated the `processVia` method in `BoardGeomBuilder` to use the new via geometry functions, explicitly generating copper and drill geometries, clipping copper to the board if needed, subtracting the drill from the board, and cutting through pads. https://linear.app/tscircuit/issue/TSC-177/vias-in-3d-viewer-should-have-dumbell-shape-not-cylinder-shape --- **Type and naming consistency:** * Renamed type `PCBPlatedHole` to `PcbPlatedHole` throughout `BoardGeomBuilder.ts` for consistency with other type names. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-54202078e45a6f607f1d26081355b61abf2471d14e36443ec0e3c8d3b1a03751L4-R4) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-54202078e45a6f607f1d26081355b61abf2471d14e36443ec0e3c8d3b1a03751L128-R128) [[3]](diffhunk://#diff-54202078e45a6f607f1d26081355b61abf2471d14e36443ec0e3c8d3b1a03751L539-R540) **Codebase simplification and minor fixes:** * Removed unused `holeGeoms` property from `BoardGeomBuilder` to clean up the class. * Improved switch-case handling for `cutout.shape` in `BoardGeomBuilder` by adding braces for clarity and maintainability. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-54202078e45a6f607f1d26081355b61abf2471d14e36443ec0e3c8d3b1a03751L417-R416) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-54202078e45a6f607f1d26081355b61abf2471d14e36443ec0e3c8d3b1a03751R450-R458) [[3]](diffhunk://#diff-54202078e45a6f607f1d26081355b61abf2471d14e36443ec0e3c8d3b1a03751R474) * Replaced a null check for `brepShape.outer_ring` with optional chaining for safer property access.

title: Improve mainfold via
description: Refactors the via geometry generation logic to improve the accuracy and visual representation of PCB vias, fixes a bug in drill hole processing, and adds new Storybook stories for testing and demonstration.
body: This pull request refactors the via geometry generation logic to improve the accuracy and visual representation of PCB vias, and adds new Storybook stories for testing and demonstration. The main changes include a more precise modeling of via copper geometry, a bug fix in how via drill holes are processed, and the introduction of component stories for visual validation. Ref https://linear.app/tscircuit/issue/TSC-177/vias-in-3d-viewer-should-have-dumbell-shape-not-cylinder-shape ### 3D Render ### Via geometry modeling improvements * Refactored the `createViaCopper` function in `src/utils/via-geoms.ts` to separately model the barrel and annular rings, ensuring the barrel does not exceed pad size and improving the realism of the via geometry. The drill hole is now sized to clear both pads. ### Bug fixes in via processing * Fixed a bug in `processViasForManifold` in `src/utils/manifold/process-vias.ts` by using `hole_diameter` instead of `outer_diameter` for the drill hole, ensuring correct drill sizing for each via. ### Storybook and testing enhancements * Added new stories in `stories/Via.stories.tsx` to visualize vias both with and without a PCB board, enabling easier testing and demonstration of via rendering in the `CadViewer` component.

title: Refactor: Rewrite panel tab and mousebite generation logic
description: Refactors the panel tab and mousebite generation logic to unify outline handling, improve corner handling, and simplify code structure.
body:
The previous implementation was complex, with separate logic paths for rectangular boards and boards with custom  
outlines. This has been replaced with a unified, cleaner approach.                                          

Key changes include:                                                                                              

  Unified Outline Logic: Boards defined with width and height are now treated as having a rectangular outline,   
   allowing a single logic path for all board shapes.                                                             
  New Cutout Strategy: Instead of placing multiple tabs along an edge, the new logic creates a single central gap
   for mousebites on each outline segment. The areas on either side of this gap become panel cutouts.             
  Improved Corner Handling: The system now correctly identifies convex (outside) vs. concave (inside) corners.   
   Cutouts are extended at convex corners to create a clean, continuous frame around the board, even for complex, 
   non-rectangular shapes.                                                                                        
  Code Simplification: The refactor removes redundant functions and consolidates the logic into a more           
   maintainable structure.

This PR introduces the capability to simulate buck converter circuits using the 
ngspice engine.                                                                 

  Adds a new e2e test for a buck converter circuit, validating the simulation  
   of a MOSFET, inductor, and PWM source.                                       
  Updates circuit-json-to-spice to v0.0.30 to leverage improved MOSFET

  Fixes an issue in the <inductor> component to correctly handle inductance    
   values specified as strings with units.

title: feat(panels): Support tab-routing for boards with custom outlines
description: Adds support for generating panel tabs and mouse bites for boards defined with custom outline properties, enhancing functionality for non-rectangular boards.
body:
This PR adds support for generating panel tabs and mouse bites for boards that are defined with a custom outline  
property, in addition to the existing support for rectangular boards.                                             

Key Changes:                                                                                                      

  generatePanelTabsAndMouseBitesForOutlines function: A new function has been added to specifically handle boards
   with polygonal outlines. It uses @flatten-js/core to:                                                          
     Iterate over each segment of the board's outline.                                                           
     Identify exterior edges that are not adjacent to other boards.                                              
     Algorithmically place tabs, mouse-bites, and cutouts along these exterior edges.                            
     Support non-axis-aligned edges by creating rotated rectangular pcb_cutouts.                                 
  Updated generatePanelTabsAndMouseBites: The main function now detects if a board has a custom outline and      
   delegates to the new logic. It falls back to the original implementation for simple rectangular boards.        
  New Test Case: A comprehensive test has been added in panel-with-tabs.test.tsx that panelizes eight boards with
   unique and complex polygonal outlines, verifying the result against a PCB snapshot.

title: fix(panel): correct logic that always overwrote user-provided width/height with autosized values
description: Fixes the issue where the Panel component ignored explicit width and height props, always replacing them with auto-sized values, thus preventing users from defining custom panel dimensions.
body:
### **Overview**

This PR fixes a critical issue where the `Panel` component **ignored explicit `width` and `height` props** and **always replaced them with auto-sized values**, preventing users from defining custom panel dimensions.

### **Root Cause**

`doInitialPanelLayout()` applied auto-calculated dimensions **unconditionally**, overwriting any user-provided width/height values on every initial render.

### **Fix**

The Panel logic is updated so **explicit width/height props always take precedence**, and auto-sizing only occurs when the props are *not* provided.

Key changes:

1. **`doInitialPanelLayout()`**

   * Now applies auto-calculated width/height **only when the props are `undefined`**.
   * Prevents auto-sizing from overwriting explicit user input.

2. **`doInitialPcbComponentRender()`**

   * Uses `0` as a placeholder for width/height when they are not provided, enabling proper auto-sizing in layout.

3. **`updatePcbComponentRender()`**

   * Preserves existing (possibly auto-calculated) dimensions when props remain undefined.
   * Avoids overwriting user-defined dimensions or clobbering stable auto-sized values.

### **What This Fixes**

* Users can now pass `<Panel width="100mm" height="80mm" />` and have the dimensions respected.
* Auto-sizing still works when width/height are intentionally omitted.
* Prevents unexpected layout changes caused by previously forced auto-sizing.

### **Files Changed**

* `lib/components/normal-components/Panel.ts`

  * Updated dimension-handling logic across:

    * `doInitialPanelLayout()`
    * `doInitialPcbComponentRender()`
    * `updatePcbComponentRender()`

### **Tests**

* Added: `panel-explicit-dimensions.test.tsx`

  * Verifies that explicit width/height props are now honored.
  * Ensures auto-sizing only triggers when dimensions are omitted.

### **Note**

Full autosize support (omitting width/height entirely) requires an updated release of `@tscircuit/props` where width/height fields are optional.
Local props already include this (`distance.optional()`), but core is still using **v0.0.424**, where width/height remain required.

title: Fix panel-relative board positioning and use global PCB coordinates for layout
description: Fixes issues with board positioning inside panels by using global PCB coordinates for layout, ensuring accurate absolute center computation for boards.
body:
This PR fixes multiple issues with board positioning inside panels by switching to `_getGlobalPcbPositionBeforeLayout()` for both Board and Panel. Boards now compute their absolute center correctly and panel auto-layout uses the panel's global position.

It also updates `@tscircuit/props `and adds two repro tests to validate absolute vs relative board placement


Ref:
https://linear.app/tscircuit/issue/TSC-184/manually-defining-the-pcbx-pcby-coordinates-of-a-board-inside-a-panel

title: feat: Improve default MOSFET SPICE models
description: Sets appropriate threshold voltage (VTO) and default transconductance (KP) for enhancement-mode NMOS and PMOS devices to improve their performance in switching applications.
body:
The default SPICE models for simple_mosfet components were not suitable for     
switching applications. This was due to a missing threshold voltage (VTO) and a 
low default transconductance (KP), which resulted in a high on-resistance.      

This change improves the models by:                                             

  Setting an appropriate VTO for enhancement-mode NMOS and PMOS devices.       
  Adding a default KP=0.1 to lower the MOSFET's on-resistance, making it behave
   more like an effective switch.

title: feat: Use proper MOSFET model for SPICE conversion
description: Updates the simple_mosfet SPICE conversion to use a proper MOSFET model (M device) instead of the previous voltage-controlled switch simplification.
body:
This pull request updates the simple_mosfet SPICE conversion to use a proper    
MOSFET model (M device) instead of the previous voltage-controlled switch       
simplification.                                                                 

Changes include:                                                                

  simple_mosfet components now generate M devices in the SPICE netlist.        
  The substrate is connected to the source for 3-pin MOSFET configurations.    
  Test snapshots for buck and boost converters have been updated to reflect the
   new, more accurate model.

title: feat: Add buck converter test and MOSFET channel support
description: Add support for P-channel and N-channel enhancement-mode MOSFETs and a new test case for a buck converter circuit.
body:
This change introduces support for P-channel and N-channel enhancement-mode     
MOSFETs and adds a new test case for a buck converter circuit.                  

  Implemented correct control logic for P-channel and N-channel MOSFETs in     
   circuitJsonToSpice.ts by modeling them as voltage-controlled switches with   
   appropriate polarity.                                                        
  Introduced a more realistic switch model (ENH_SW) for MOSFETs.               
  Added a new test fixture and test file for a buck converter circuit, which   
   utilizes a P-channel MOSFET, to validate the changes.                        
  Updated the existing boost converter test snapshot to reflect the new MOSFET 
   model.

This pull request adds a new user tip to the `tips` array in `lib/utils/getRandomTipForUser.ts`. The new tip informs users that they can temporarily disable autorouting during component placement and circuit design by using the `routingDisabled` prop on the `<board />` element. This helps speed up iteration cycles.

Tip: "When working on component placement and circuit design, autorouting can slow down your iteration cycle. Use [routingDisabled](https://docs.tscircuit.com/elements/board#disabling-routing-with-routingdisabled) on the <board /> element to disable autorouting temporarily."

Hey @seveibar  , can we please add this tip, this helped me a lot when developing sparkfun boards

title: Watch node_modules/*/dist/index.js by modifying should-ignore-path to not ignore the path
description: Enables the DevServer to watch node_modulesdistindex.js files for changes, including scoped packages, by modifying the should-ignore-path pattern.
body:
Fixes TSC-180


This fix enables the DevServer to watch `node_modules/*/dist/index.js` files for changes (including scoped packages like @scope/pkg/dist/index.js). Since chokidar checks each directory level when traversing, we use brace expansion to allow all parent directories in the pathotherwise chokidar stops at `node_modules` and never reaches the target files. The pattern `!node_modules{,/*,/*/dist,/*/dist/index.js,/@*,/@*/*,/@*/*/dist,/@*/*/dist/index.js}` compactly negates all required paths so chokidar can descend into `node_modules` and watch only the specific `dist/index.js` files while still ignoring everything else.

title: docs: expand board properties and add detailed usage examples
description: This PR expands the documentation for the board component by adding new properties for customizing PCB design and providing detailed usage examples.
body:
This pull request significantly expands the documentation for the `<board>` component, adding detailed explanations and new properties for customizing PCB design. The changes introduce several new props related to board appearance, manufacturing options, and development workflow, as well as usage examples and explanations to help users understand and leverage these features.

The most important changes are:

#### New board properties and customization options

* Added new props to the `<board>` component: `routingDisabled`, `material`, `thickness`, `title`, `solderMaskColor`, `topSolderMaskColor`, `bottomSolderMaskColor`, `silkscreenColor`, `topSilkscreenColor`, `bottomSilkscreenColor`, `doubleSidedAssembly`, `boardAnchorPosition`, `boardAnchorAlignment`, `defaultTraceWidth`, and `minTraceWidth`, with descriptions and usage guidance.
* Restricted the `layers` prop to accepted values (`1 | 2 | 4 | 6 | 8`) instead of any number, clarifying supported stackups.

#### Enhanced documentation and examples

* Added detailed documentation sections for new props, including explanations and code samples for `routingDisabled`, board material and color customization, double-sided assembly, and trace width control. [[1]](diffhunk://#diff-8158663796de21f7acff328bfbc7670f3923946326126d30641e43919d5ced78L34-R135) [[2]](diffhunk://#diff-8158663796de21f7acff328bfbc7670f3923946326126d30641e43919d5ced78R159-R161) [[3]](diffhunk://#diff-8158663796de21f7acff328bfbc7670f3923946326126d30641e43919d5ced78R183-R205)
* Provided examples and rationale for using `routingDisabled` to speed up development by skipping autorouting during early design stages.
* Added explanation and example for specifying board thickness using the `thickness` prop, emphasizing its importance for mechanical and electrical properties.

These updates make the documentation more comprehensive and user-friendly, enabling users to better understand and utilize advanced board configuration options.

title: feat: Add configurable iterative trace simplification solver
description: Adds a configurable iterative trace simplification solver that optimizes PCB traces by consolidating multiple pipeline steps into a single maintainable component.
body:
ref: https://discord.com/channels/1233487248129921135/1446762452556709912/1446763245116461137

## Summary
- Introduces TraceSimplificationSolver to optimize PCB traces through configurable iterations of via removal and path simplification
- Consolidates 4 separate pipeline steps into a single, maintainable solver with adjustable iteration count

## Details
The new `TraceSimplificationSolver` provides iterative trace optimization by alternating between two phases:
1. **Via Removal**: Removes unnecessary vias using `UselessViaRemovalSolver`
2. **Path Simplification**: Simplifies routing paths using `MultiSimplifiedPathSolver`

The solver runs these phases in sequence for a configurable number of iterations (default: 2), producing cleaner routes with fewer unnecessary vias.

### Benefits
- **Cleaner Routes**: Produces optimized traces with minimal vias
- **Configurable**: Iteration count can be adjusted based on complexity needs
- **Maintainable**: Consolidates repetitive optimization logic into a single component
- **Extensible**: Easy to add new optimization phases in the future

### Pipeline Integration
Replaces 4 separate solver steps in `AutoroutingPipelineSolver`:
- `uselessViaRemovalSolver1` + `multiSimplifiedPathSolver1` + `uselessViaRemovalSolver2` + `multiSimplifiedPathSolver2`

With a single configurable step:
- `traceSimplificationSolver` (iterations: 2)

title: Improve route stitching algorithm and add Z-lock constraints for target nodes
description: Refactors the route stitching logic and fixes layer assignment issues in the unravel solver by removing the RouteDirectionFixSubSolver, improving route stitching selection with a scoring system, adding Z-lock constraints for target nodes, and handling edge cases in the SingleSimplifiedPathSolver.
body:
This PR refactors the route stitching logic and fixes layer assignment issues in the unravel solver.
Key changes:

- Removed RouteDirectionFixSubSolver: The route direction optimization is now handled within SingleHighDensityRouteStitchSolver, simplifying the pipeline.
- Improved route stitching selection: Replaced the "disjoint route" heuristic with a scoring system that prioritizes same-layer connections, then via transitions, then gap bridging. This handles small gaps and multi-layer routes more robustly.
- Added Z-lock for target nodes: Segment points inside nodes containing targets can no longer have their Z (layer) changed during unraveling. This prevents the solver from moving traces off-layer at connection points, fixing routing failures.
- Edge case fix: Handle when layer change occurs at the last point in SingleSimplifiedPathSolver5_Deg45.

title: Feat: Enforce tstep by interpolating simulation results
description: This PR resamples simulation output to enforce the tstep parameter from the .tran command, ensuring data is returned with the precise tstep specified by the user through linear interpolation.
body:
This pull request resamples simulation output to      
enforce the tstep parameter from the .tran command. The underlying simulation   
engine uses an adaptive timestep, which can differ from the requested           
resolution.                                                                     

This is achieved by introducing a manual resampling step that linearly          
interpolates the simulation results. This ensures the data is returned with the 
precise tstep specified by the user, leading to more predictable and accurate   
simulation graphs.                                                              

Changes include:                                                                

  A new linearInterpolate function to perform resampling.                      
  Integration of this function into eecircuitResultToVGraphs to process the    
   data before it's returned.                                                   
  A new test file with timestep-specific snapshot tests to verify the feature  
   and prevent regressions.

title: Add Smart Trace-Margin Rasterization for Automated PCB Laser-Cut Clearance Generation
description: Summary This PR introduces automated trace-margin rasterization, enabling precise laser-cut electrical-isolation zones around PCB traces. It generates accurate clearance regions and fills them with 45 crosshatched raster patterns using LightBurns Scan modesignificantly improving copper removal quality and fabrication reliability for laser-ablated PCBs. ---  Changes   New Features Automatic trace-margin clearance generation Computes the clearance area between normal-width traces and expanded traces (width  2margin) to create accurate isolation donut geometries. Crosshatch rasterization for copper removal Uses LightBurns Scan mode with a 45 crosshatch pattern for efficient and consistent margin ablation. Per-layer margin cut settings Provides dedicated cut settings for top and bottom copper clearances (LightBurn layer indices 4  5). Configurable laser spot size Laser spot size (default 0.005 mm) controls crosshatch spacing for optimized ablation performance. ---  API Changes New optional parameters added to convertCircuitJsonToLbrn: traceMargin?: number  Margin width (mm) for trace clearance (requires includeCopper: true) laserSpotSize?: number  Laser spot size (mm) for crosshatch spacing (default: 0.005mm) All parameters are fully optional and backward compatible. ---  Robustness Improvements More resilient boolean-ops handling for complex geometries that previously broke flatten-js Automatic fallback to per-polygon output when unioning fails Detailed warning logs help diagnose problematic trace shapes ---  Documentation Expanded README with full trace-margin workflow description Added examples, diagrams, and best-practice notes Documented all new API parameters and recommended usage patterns ---  Testing  Basic trace-margin test (simple horizontal trace)  Validation of invalid configurations (e.g., using traceMargin without copper)  Complex real-world circuit test (25-LED grid  ESP32)  All existing tests pass (4242) ---  Implementation Details Trace-margin generation works by: 1. Generating normal-width trace geometry (inner union) 2. Generating expanded-width geometry using width  2traceMargin (outer union) 3. Computing clearanceArea  outer  inner, producing margin rings 4. Exporting these areas as filled crosshatch Scan-mode shapes This design is highly efficient because it: Clears only the required isolation zonesnot entire copper layers Avoids error-prone manual offsetboolean geometry Uses LightBurns built-in optimized crosshatch engine Ensures reliable isolation by fully eliminating leftover conductive paths ---  Example Usage ts const lbrn  convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson,  includeCopper: true, traceMargin: 0.2,  0.2mm clearance laserSpotSize: 0.005,  5m crosshatch spacing includeLayers: top, );  ---  Breaking Changes None. All new functionality is optional and preserves existing behavior.
body:
### **Summary**

This PR introduces **automated trace-margin rasterization**, enabling precise laser-cut electrical-isolation zones around PCB traces. It generates accurate clearance regions and fills them with **45 crosshatched raster patterns** using LightBurns Scan modesignificantly improving copper removal quality and fabrication reliability for laser-ablated PCBs.

---

### **Changes**

## ** New Features**

* **Automatic trace-margin clearance generation**
  Computes the clearance area between normal-width traces and expanded traces (width + 2margin) to create accurate isolation donut geometries.

* **Crosshatch rasterization for copper removal**
  Uses LightBurns **Scan mode** with a **45 crosshatch pattern** for efficient and consistent margin ablation.

* **Per-layer margin cut settings**
  Provides dedicated cut settings for **top** and **bottom** copper clearances (LightBurn layer indices 4 & 5).

* **Configurable laser spot size**
  Laser spot size (default **0.005 mm**) controls crosshatch spacing for optimized ablation performance.

---

### **API Changes**

New optional parameters added to `convertCircuitJsonToLbrn`:

* **traceMargin?: number**  Margin width (mm) for trace clearance (requires `includeCopper: true`)
* **laserSpotSize?: number**  Laser spot size (mm) for crosshatch spacing (default: 0.005mm)

All parameters are fully optional and **backward compatible**.

---

### **Robustness Improvements**

* More resilient boolean-ops handling for complex geometries that previously broke `flatten-js`
* Automatic fallback to per-polygon output when unioning fails
* Detailed warning logs help diagnose problematic trace shapes

---

### **Documentation**

* Expanded README with full trace-margin workflow description
* Added examples, diagrams, and best-practice notes
* Documented all new API parameters and recommended usage patterns

---

### **Testing**

*  Basic trace-margin test (simple horizontal trace)
*  Validation of invalid configurations (e.g., using traceMargin without copper)
*  Complex real-world circuit test (25-LED grid + ESP32)
*  All existing tests pass (**42/42**)

---

### **Implementation Details**

Trace-margin generation works by:

1. Generating normal-width trace geometry (inner union)
2. Generating expanded-width geometry using **width + 2traceMargin** (outer union)
3. Computing **clearanceArea = outer  inner**, producing margin rings
4. Exporting these areas as **filled crosshatched Scan-mode shapes**

This design is highly efficient because it:

* Clears **only** the required isolation zonesnot entire copper layers
* Avoids error-prone manual offset/boolean geometry
* Uses LightBurns built-in optimized crosshatch engine
* Ensures reliable isolation by fully eliminating leftover conductive paths

---

### **Example Usage**

```ts
const lbrn = convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson, {
  includeCopper: true,
  traceMargin: 0.2,      // 0.2mm clearance
  laserSpotSize: 0.005,  // 5m crosshatch spacing
  includeLayers: ["top"],
});
```

---

### **Breaking Changes**

None.
All new functionality is optional and preserves existing behavior.

---

title: Introduce full multi-layer copper architecture with dedicated top/bottom processing and via-aware trace splitting
description: Summary This PR introduces a full multi-layer copper architecture featuring independent top and bottom copper processing, precise via-aware trace splitting, and flexible layer-selective export. These improvements elevate the converter to true multi-layer PCB capability and enable advanced manufacturing workflows such as selective laser cutting, single-side operations, and accurate double-sided production. Key Enhancements 1. Dedicated TopBottom Copper Layers Replaces the previous single copper pipeline Each layer receives its own geometry and cut settings Supports double-sided PCB workflows with proper layer isolation 2. Via-Aware Multi-Layer Trace Splitting Correctly segments traces at vias Distributes trace geometry to the appropriate copper layer Ensures accurate copper distribution across stackups 3. New includeLayers Option (with full examples) The converter now allows exporting any combination of copper layers: tsx  Process all layers (default) convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson)  Process only top layer convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson,  includeLayers: top )  Process only bottom layer convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson,  includeLayers: bottom )  Process both layers explicitly (bottom, top is equivalent to default) convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson,  includeLayers: bottom, top )  Supports single-sided manufacturing Allows explicit multi-layer selection Maintains full backward compatibility 4. Updated Element Handling SMT Pads: Routed based on layer property Traces: Grouped and processed by copper layer Vias  Plated Holes: Added to both copper layers  through-board layer Reflects real-world multi-layer PCB behavior Cut Settings Update Previous: Copper Through Board Soldermask New: Top Copper (index 0) Bottom Copper (index 1) Through Board (index 2) Soldermask (index 3) This provides granular control but introduces index changes. Motivation The previous single-layer approach prevented accurate multi-layer export, limiting: Side-specific laser settings Selective production of top or bottom side Correct representation of traces that change layers via vias This PR removes these limitations and establishes a robust, production-ready multi-layer pipeline. Testing  Validation  All 39 existing tests pass  Comprehensive multi-layer tests added (using keyboard-default60.json)  Verified trace splitting at vias  Verified per-layer filtering and geometry isolation Tested on a 183-trace multi-layer board: All layers  Top: 402, Bottom: 512, Through: 455 Top only  402  through-board Bottom only  512  through-board Both explicitly  Same as all layers Breaking Changes  Cut setting indices updated: Soldermask: 2  3 Through Board: 1  2 Projects that reference indices numerically may require updates. It significantly improves correctness, configurability, and production readiness.
body:
### Summary

This PR introduces a full multi-layer copper architecture featuring independent top and bottom copper processing, precise via-aware trace splitting, and flexible layer-selective export. These improvements elevate the converter to true multi-layer PCB capability and enable advanced manufacturing workflows such as selective laser cutting, single-side operations, and accurate double-sided production.

Key Enhancements

1. Dedicated Top/Bottom Copper Layers
		Replaces the previous single copper pipeline
		Each layer receives its own geometry and cut settings
		Supports double-sided PCB workflows with proper layer isolation

2. Via-Aware Multi-Layer Trace Splitting
		Correctly segments traces at vias
		Distributes trace geometry to the appropriate copper layer
		Ensures accurate copper distribution across stackups

3. New includeLayers Option (with full examples)

The converter now allows exporting any combination of copper layers:
```tsx
// Process all layers (default)
convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson)

// Process only top layer
convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson, { includeLayers: ["top"] })

// Process only bottom layer
convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson, { includeLayers: ["bottom"] })

// Process both layers explicitly (["bottom", "top"] is equivalent to default)
convertCircuitJsonToLbrn(circuitJson, { includeLayers: ["bottom", "top"] })
```

		Supports single-sided manufacturing
		Allows explicit multi-layer selection
		Maintains full backward compatibility

4. Updated Element Handling
		SMT Pads: Routed based on layer property
		Traces: Grouped and processed by copper layer
		Vias / Plated Holes: Added to both copper layers + through-board layer
		Reflects real-world multi-layer PCB behavior

Cut Settings Update

Previous:
		Copper
		Through Board
		Soldermask

New:
		Top Copper (index 0)
		Bottom Copper (index 1)
		Through Board (index 2)
		Soldermask (index 3)

This provides granular control but introduces index changes.

Motivation

The previous single-layer approach prevented accurate multi-layer export, limiting:
		Side-specific laser settings
		Selective production of top or bottom side
		Correct representation of traces that change layers via vias

This PR removes these limitations and establishes a robust, production-ready multi-layer pipeline.

Testing & Validation
		 All 39 existing tests pass
		 Comprehensive multi-layer tests added (using keyboard-default60.json)
		 Verified trace splitting at vias
		 Verified per-layer filtering and geometry isolation
		Tested on a 183-trace multi-layer board:
		All layers  Top: 402, Bottom: 512, Through: 455
		Top only  402 + through-board
		Bottom only  512 + through-board
		Both explicitly  Same as all layers

Breaking Changes

 Cut setting indices updated:
		Soldermask: 2  3
		Through Board: 1  2
Projects that reference indices numerically may require updates.

Conclusion

This PR delivers a complete, robust multi-layer copper system, enabling precise top/bottom separation, accurate via segmentation, and flexible layer inclusion for manufacturing workflows. It significantly improves correctness, configurability, and production readiness.

title: Add normalization for plus and minus symbols in pin names and silkscreen text
description: Normalizes pin names and silkscreen text by converting literal  and - symbols to safe identifiers _POS and _NEG to prevent converter breakage.
body:
Summary
I have successfully implemented the fix for the issue where EasyEDA symbol or pin names that are literally "+" or "-" break the converter. Here's what i have done : 
1. Created Normalization Helper Function
- File: lib/utils/normalize-symbol-name.ts
- Function: normalizeSymbolName(name: string): string
- Logic: 
  - "+"  "_POS"
  - "-"  "_NEG"
  - Otherwise returns the original trimmed name
2. Applied Normalization in Conversion Pipeline
- File: lib/convert-easyeda-json-to-tscircuit-soup-json.ts
- Applied to:
  - Pin labels: Line 235 - normalizeSymbolName(pin.label)
  - Silkscreen text: Line 472 - normalizeSymbolName(shape.text)
3. Added Comprehensive Tests
- Unit tests: tests/normalize-symbol-name.test.ts - Tests the helper function directly
- Integration tests: tests/convert-to-soup-tests/normalize-plus-minus.test.ts - Tests normalization in the full conversion pipeline
4. Verification
- All existing tests pass (69 tests)
- Code formatting is correct
- TypeScript compilation succeeds
- No regressions introduced
The implementation is minimal, clean, and focused on the specific issue. The normalization function is applied exactly where needed:
- Pin names/labels during pin label processing
- Text content during silkscreen text generation
This ensures that any literal "+" or "-" symbols in EasyEDA data are converted to safe identifiers "_POS" and "_NEG" that won't break the converter or downstream processing.

/fix #285

title: Fixed SparkFun-Air-Velocity-Sensor-Breakout-FS3000-1015
description: Adds a new component definition for the SM04B_SRSS_TB_LF connector and updates its usage in the SparkFun Air Velocity Sensor Breakout board design.
body:
This pull request introduces a new component definition for the SM04B_SRSS_TB_LF connector and updates its usage in the SparkFun Air Velocity Sensor Breakout board design to use this new version. The main changes focus on adding the new `SM04B_SRSS_TB_LF__SN2` component and replacing the previous version in the board circuit.

**New component definition and usage update:**

* Added a new file `SM04B_SRSS_TB_LF__SN2.tsx` that defines the SM04B_SRSS_TB_LF connector with explicit pin labels, footprint details, silkscreen paths, and a CAD model reference.
* Imported the new `SM04B_SRSS_TB_LF__SN2` component in `SparkFun-Air-Velocity-Sensor-Breakout-FS3000-1015.circuit.tsx` and replaced the previous `SM04B_SRSS_TB_LF__SN` instance with the new version for JP7. title: Add the SesHostCad and SesHostVersion class
description: Adds the SesHostCad and SesHostVersion classes to represent host CAD tool information and version in the SES parser.

title: Add the visualize on the `CollectSesRoutesStage` to view all the trace segments
description: Adds functionality to visualize trace segments in the SesRoutesViewer component, allowing users to toggle between layer and trace color modes for better differentiation of PCB traces.

title: Add the visualization for the `CollectSesRoutesStage` via the motor-driver-board example
description: This pull request introduces a new visualization component for the CollectSesRoutesStage, allowing users to visualize PCB traces and vias from a motor driver example. It includes a new SesRoutesViewer class that extends the base solver to handle the visualization of traces and vias, providing a graphical representation of the routing process. The implementation includes scaling for visibility and detailed statistics about the traces.
